dc:source.dc:abstract: Isolated dystonia is a disorder characterized by involuntary twisting postures arising from sustained muscle contractions. Although autosomal-dominant mutations in TOR1A, THAP1, and GNAL have been found in some cases, the molecular mechanisms underlying isolated dystonia are largely unknown. In addition, although emphasis has been placed on dominant isolated dystonia, the disorder is also transmitted as a recessive trait, for which no mutations have been defined. Using whole-exome sequencing in a recessive isolated dystonia-affected kindred, we identified disease-segregating compound heterozygous mutations in COL6A3, a collagen VI gene associated previously with muscular dystrophy. Genetic screening of a further 367 isolated dystonia subjects revealed two additional recessive pedigrees harboring compound heterozygous mutations in COL6A3. Strikingly, all affected individuals had at least one pathogenic allele in exon 41, including an exon-skipping mutation that induced an in-frame deletion. We tested the hypothesis that disruption of this exon is pathognomonic for isolated dystonia by inducing a series of in-frame deletions in zebrafish embryos. Consistent with our human genetics data, suppression of the exon 41 ortholog caused deficits in axonal outgrowth, whereas suppression of other exons phenocopied collagen deposition mutants. All recessive mutation carriers demonstrated early-onset segmental isolated dystonia without muscular disease. Finally, we show that Col6a3 is expressed in neurons, with relevant mRNA levels detectable throughout the adult mouse brain. Taken together, our data indicate that loss-of-function mutations affecting a specific region of COL6A3 cause recessive isolated dystonia with underlying neurodevelopmental deficits and highlight the brain extracellular matrix as a contributor to dystonia pathogenesis.
dc:source.dc:creator: Zech M
dc:source.dc:title: Recessive mutations in the Î±3 (VI) collagen gene COL6A3 cause early-onset isolated dystonia.

evidence.dc:description: No functional evidence for these two variants.
No points given becuase of high MAF of variant. Present in 0.28% (29/10370) Ashkenazi Jewish & 0.11% (144/129170) European (non-Finnish) alleles & in 2 homozygotes in South Asian pop.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: involuntary twisted posturing of the right hand for the past two years, initially intermittent, appearing while writing and approaching to grasp any object, intermittent action tremors of the right hand, poor handwriting, dystonia of proximal part of the right upper limb and cervical dystonia with extensor posturing of the neck in resting state, oromandibular dystonia, drooling, dysarthria, and intermit-tent dystonic posturing of the right upper limb along with tremors

dc:source.dc:abstract: Still, the genetic basis of a large number of cases of early-onset isolated dystonia continues to be a mystery. In recent years, many new candidate genes are being identified as putative pathogenic factors in children with isolated dystonia due to the easy availability of whole-exome sequencing. Recently biallelic mutations in the COL6A3 gene were identified as a cause of rare dystonia (DYT)-27 syndrome. Till date, only six cases of DYT27 have been reported in the literature.
dc:source.dc:creator: Panda PK
dc:source.dc:title: COL6A3 mutation associated early-onset isolated dystonia (DYT)-27: Report of a new case and review of published literature.

evidence.rdfs:label: Panda Proband

evidence.dc:description: No functional evidence for either variant.
RNA sequencing data of mouse brain shows expression in murine brainstem, dorsal midbrain, and ventral midbrain.

evidence.dc:description: RNA seq data shows expression of COL6A3 in zebrafish heads 5 dpf

evidence.dc:description: Zebrafish model provides a mechanism for how dystonia phenotype can occur in humans.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebrafish model

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded by 1 point because morpholino's weren't shown to be specific.

dc:description: COL6A3 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive dystonia in 2015 (Zech et al., PMID: 26004199). At least 5 variants (missense, in-frame indel) have been reported in humans. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. Three probands in 2 publications (PMIDs: 26004199, 32037012) are included in this curation. The mechanism of pathogenicity is unknown. This gene-disease association is also supported by an animal model and expression studies (PMID: 26004199). In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Congenital Myopathy GCEP on the meeting date 5/24/21 (SOP Version 8).
